text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 1.14.4, Personal Property Management.
Updated the reorganization of Facilities Management and Security Services (FMSS).
This supersedes IRM 1.14.4 dated April 30, 2018.
AUDIENCE
Table of Contents
Personal Property Management

) Purpose: Property and Asset Management (P&AM) is the ongoing process and function of maintaining physical accountability of IRS assets throughout their lifecycle. The process uses various property management tools for tracking, value reporting, and chain of custody of IRS non-Information ogy (IT) assets through acquisition to ﬁnal disposal. These tools help to mitigate vulnerability to theft, waste, fraud, or abuse. (
) Audience: This policy applies to IRS employees who are responsible and ac- countable for acquiring, barcoding, maintaining, inventorying and controlling non-IT assets. (
) Policy Owner: Facilities Management and Security Services (FMSS) is the program office responsible for overseeing the P&AM Program and providing guidance to each IRS business unit. (
) Program Owner: FMSS, Facilities Support, Logistics. (

) Primary Stakeholders: Each IRS business unit is a partner of the P&AM Program. FMSS, IT, Criminal Investigation (CI) and the Chief Financial Officer (CFO) are primarily impacted by the changes to the policies and procedures. IT/User & Network Services (UNS) is the business process owner of asset inventory data. IT/UNS partners with FMSS, CI, Chief Counsel (CC) the other IT component organizations who are accountable and responsible verifying and certifying hardware assets under their respective control and stewardship. (

) Program Goals: The P&AM Program serves as the IRS lead in the lifecycle management of non-IT accountable assets tracked in KISAM-AM system and in the disposal of IT assets. The program supports IRS goals and objectives sustainability and recycling/reuse efforts. Note: P&AM program disposes of most assets, not all.

Stakeholders: Each IRS business unit is a partner of the P&AM FMSS, IT, Criminal Investigation (CI) and the Chief Financial Officer are primarily impacted by the changes to the policies and procedures. & Network Services (UNS) is the business process owner of inventory data. ) This IRM provides purpose, authorities, directives, and responsibilities for the P&AM Program. (
) P&AM includes the process, people, and systems that provide effective ac- counting and internal controls of personal property throughout its lifecycle acquisition through ﬁnal disposal). (
) FMSS Headquarters (HQ) P&AM Program has oversight for the management of non-IT IRS assets and administers the program in compliance with IRM

) The P&AM Program requires the participation of FMSS Territory Managers (TM) and employees to ensure separation of duties, support internal and Quality Assurance (QA) program reviews, adherence to regulations, protect employees from any appearance of bias or misappropriation of ment assets. (

) The FMSS designated HQ Program Manager is responsible for: a. Conducting regular reviews of FMSS Territory P&AM Program utilizing data from Knowledge Incident/Problem Service Asset ment Asset Manager (KISAM-AM) ﬁelds: Assignment, Barcode, Serial Number, Building Code, Contact/User. b. Providing guidance and policy clariﬁcation to FMSS Territory Property staff regarding FMSS P&AM User Guide or answering concerns. c. Coordinating with each business unit and external stakeholders on policy and guidance. d. Providing completed HQ reviews with corrective requirements and tions to the FMSS Territory Property staff and their managers. e. Acting as a FMSS Approving Authority for IRS disposal documents. f. Conducting internal control reviews (timeliness and accuracy of data) regarding the P&AM Program processes within their territory. (
) The FMSS TM and/or Section Chiefs are responsible for: a. Verifying that the Territory P&AM Program has committed resources to support the program responsibilities.
Note: Additional guidance can be found on the P&AM Sharepoint site.
Management
b. Reviewing the P&AM dashboard measures to monitor territory health. c. Verifying that IRS acquisition documents are reviewed and that required to be accounted for in KISAM-AM are added within

days. d. Reviewing and signing IRS disposal documents timely (prior to the physical disposal action) as the approving authority for both IT and non-IT personal property, whether tracked in KISAM-AM or not. e. Validating territory program review corrections are completed timely accurately. f. Validating the accuracy of the Territory KISAM-AM annual inventory signing the annual Territory Inventory Certiﬁcation Memo. g. Correcting identiﬁed anomalies identiﬁed in the Territory KISAM-AM annual inventory reconciliation plan on or before the annual due date and validating corrections were completed by signing the Territory Reconciliation Memo. h. Verifying excess non-IT personal property follows all regulatory ments and documentation is available for reviews and audits. (

) The FMSS Territory Property Officer is accountable and responsible for cycle management of IRS personal property, which includes following program processes and procedures within their territory. Other FMSS employees may assist with the responsibilities as assigned by the TM or Section Chief. (

) The FMSS Territory KISAM-AM Coordinator is the territory employee who accountable and responsible for maintaining non-IT asset records and activities in KISAM-AM. This employee may be the same employee(s) as FMSS Territory Property Officer. (

) Program Reports: The KISAM-AM system is the central repository used processing all basic accountability actions related to the entire lifecycle of and non-IT assets, KISAM-AM records, and tracks accountable non-IT asset sitions, transfers, moves, and disposals. a. Acquisition Reports are stored in Procurement for Public Sector (or its successor program). non-IT asset purchases that meet the accountable threshold or threshold are added into KISAM-AM. The acquisition information Purchase Order (PO)) is a mandatory data ﬁeld in the KISAM-AM record. These reports support accuracy, timeliness, accountability, chain of custody, and auditability. c. Disposal Reports document the ﬁnal disposal action where IRS no longer has ownership or title of an asset. d. SAP Business Objects Environment (BOE) provides many reports from data in KISAM-AM and PPS, which are used for the review of asset management processes such as timely disposal, annual inventory valida- tion and certiﬁcation, and anomaly reports both for IT and non-IT assets.

) Program Effectiveness: Success of the P&AM Program is measured by verifying: a. Deﬁciencies/problems are corrected timely and accurately as Program Reviews’ instructions. b. New non-IT assets are added to KISAM-AM after receipt and in PPS. c. Non-IT annual inventory certiﬁcation and validation by June

d. Non-IT assets, including furniture in a real estate project, are for reuse. Note: If assets cannot be reused, they should be exchanged. If cannot be reused or exchanged, they must be excessed. e. IT asset disposal cycle time is
days or less with a

% timeliness score excluding extenuating circumstances. Example: Extenuating circumstances such as, epidemics, weather disasters, etc. f. Dedicated resources to support the program are expended. This is measured by reviewing time recorded in the IRS timekeeping system, Single Entry Time Reporting (SETR), using the P&AM Program code (
). g. Audit recommendations and Planned Corrective Actions (PCA) are executed in the territories as prescribed in the recommendations or PCAs. (

) Abandoned or Unclaimed Property - Personal property found on IRS premises owned or leased by the government and subject to the ﬁling of claims by former owner(s) within three years from the vesting of title in the United States. (

) Accountable Property - All non-expendable property for which is established in the perpetual inventory accounts (KISAM-AM) and the ledger. It is property of durable nature with a useful life of more than one has sufficient value to justify maintaining and continuing ﬁnancial property records, is of a nature that moderate damage results in repair rather than placement, and generally costs $
or more. (

) Asset - Any property other than real estate. The distinguishing factor personal property and real property is that personal property is movable not ﬁxed permanently to one location, such as land or buildings. able with personal property. (

) Capitalized Property - An accounting/ﬁnance term used on the agency ﬁnancial statement. This property has different dollar threshold controlled by the CFO Office. Not to be confused with Accountable that requires tracking in KISAM-AM. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
P

tions, relocations).

Abandoned or Unclaimed Property - Personal property found on IRS premises owned or leased by the government and subject to the ﬁling of claims by former owner(s) within three years from the vesting of title in the United States. Accountable Property - All non-expendable property for which is established in the perpetual inventory accounts (KISAM-AM) and the ledger. It is property of durable nature with a useful life of more than one has sufficient value to justify maintaining and continuing ﬁnancial property records, is of a nature that moderate damage results in repair rather than placement, and generally costs $

or more. Asset - Any property other than real estate. The distinguishing factor personal property and real property is that personal property is movable and not ﬁxed permanently to one location, such as land or buildings. able with personal property. Capitalized Property - An accounting/ﬁnance term used on the agency ﬁnancial statement. This property has different dollar threshold requirements controlled by the CFO Office. Not to be confused with Accountable Property that requires tracking in KISAM-AM.
(04-30-2018) Terms/Deﬁnitions/ Acronyms
Management
) Condition Codes - An alpha or numeric code that describes the physical condition and serviceability of personal property as prescribed by the FMR. (
) Excess Personal Property - Any property under the control of any federal agency not required for its needs and the discharge of its responsibilities, determined by the agency head. (
) Executive Agency - An executive department, military department, or any dependent establishment, within the meaning of
USC
, and
respectively, and wholly-owned government corporation within the meaning
USC

) Expendable/Consumable Property - All property that is used up beyond recovery, loses its identity, or becomes a component part of other ﬁxed property. Usually is an item of supply (except explosive ordnance, end items of equipment, and repairables) (e.g., Non-repairable items or parts that can be discarded more economically than they can be repaired, pencils, pens, paper, dried up markers, batteries, etc.). (

) Federal Agency - An executive agency or any independent establishment the legislative or judicial branch of the Government (except the Senate, the House of Representatives, or the Architect of the Capitol, and any activities under the Architect’s direction). (
) Forfeited Property - Personal property acquired by a federal agency either a summary process or by order of a court of competent jurisdiction any law of the United States. (

) High Risk or Sensitive - A unique classiﬁcation given to assets, that special control and accountability due to unusual rates of loss, theft, ability to store IRS data, ease of removal, and the risk of impacting the IRS mission. These assets are recorded and tracked in KISAM-AM if their tion is $
or greater. (
) Investigative Equipment - CI equipment required by CI for carrying out its investigative and enforcement functions. See IRM
, Administrative Databases and Software, Criminal Investigation Management Information System Equipment Inventory. (
) Maintenance - The scheduled cleaning, servicing, and adjustment of an to keep it in satisfactory operating condition. (

) Personal Property - Any property other than real estate. The distinguishing factor between personal property and real property is that personal property movable and not ﬁxed permanently to one location, such as land or Interchangeable with asset. (

) Repair - The restoration of an asset to a serviceable or operable condition from an unserviceable or inoperable condition, which resulted from wear, breakage, or partial destruction. The overall objective is to restore or assets to a near-new condition. (

) Unconditional (in-kind) Gifts - Gifts of more than minimal value (minimal value is deﬁned by GSA) received by federal employees, their spouses, or pendents from a foreign government are deemed to have been accepted on behalf of the United States and, upon acceptance, become the property of United States. Facilities (

) KISAM-AM is the authoritative source for all Hardware Asset Management inventory information within IRS and supersedes other inventory data General KISAM-AM is the official IRS centralized asset management inventory - System database of all IT and non-IT personal property that meets the speciﬁed threshold/reportable criteria. It is a subsidiary account to the general ledger managing personal property. KISAM-AM tracks each item of accountable property through the asset’s lifecycle (acquisition through ﬁnal disposal). a. Non-IT assets accountable and inventoried on KISAM-AM are those vidual assets with an acquisition cost of $

or more and all designated “high-risk” non-IT assets with an acquisition cost of more. Exception: Investigative equipment and CI investigative/surveillance motor vehicles are controlled by CI on the CIMIS. IRS vehicles are maintained by the HQ Motor Vehicle Fleet Program Manager. (

) Each ﬁscal year, all FMSS territory offices are required to conduct a inventory of all non-IT assets meeting IRS speciﬁed criteria. The HQ P&AM Program Manager will issue an annual control to notify the territory offices the timeline and due date. As part of the inventory, offices are required to reconcile all missing assets using the Non-IT Missing Asset Checklist with KISAM-AM system and address any assets awaiting disposal longer than calendar days. (

) FMSS management strives to ensure no employee is responsible for more than two of the following duties and functions. of Duties a. Acquiring property (using their government credit card or the Point(s) Contact (POC) for a procurement action above the designated b. Receiving property. c. Inventorying property into KISAM-AM. d. Signing disposal documents as the reviewer/submitter. e. Acting as a Project Manager on a real estate project (cannot prepare sign IRS disposal documents). Note: A Project Manager cannot “act” as an FMSS Territory Property Officer on their own project. (

) All IRS employees are responsible for the proper care and protection of ernment property they use or have in their possession. Any employee and witnessing a violation of this responsibility must report it to his/her of Personal supervisor. (
) All IRS employees must promptly report the loss of any IRS asset within hour of discovery of the loss following the directions in IRM
) All IRS employees are responsible for promptly requesting needed repairs property. (

) Under federal regulations, each agency must establish quantitative and monetary controls over its personal property. (

) KISAM-AM provides IRS with the official complete record of perpetual inventory accounts for IT and non-IT assets, which meets the control for the IRS general ledger accounts. Accountability in the ﬁscal context includes reporting on the use of funds and recording the events and tions involving an IRS asset. This process provides historical information the asset’s value throughout its lifecycle. (

) IRS managers are responsible for all property within their span of control to safeguard it from loss, breakage, or undue deterioration until the FMSS Territory Property Officer authorizes its removal through a submitted OS Services ticket - Non-IT Property Disposal. a. With approval, employees can remove property from IRS offices to an offsite location to conduct official business. Approval must be given by the employee’s manager and the FMSS Territory Property Officer an OS Ge
ervices ticket - Property Consultation. The property must returned to the office as soon as it is practical. b. The employee is responsible to safeguard the property while it is (

) IRS employees may only use personally-owned property for official use if thorized by IRS or Treasury regulations. Requests to use personally owned property for official use must be submitted to the FMSS Territory Property Officer through an OS Ge
ervices ticket - Property Consultation. (
) Asset Management records are to be established and maintained in accor- dance with PGLD Guidance. Each FMSS territory maintains their own property record ﬁles (electronic or hard copy). (
) General Record Schedule (GRS)
used for Property Disposal Records GRS
used for Budget Preparation, Presentation, and Apportionment can both be found in Document

) Reports are compiled by each of the FMSS territories and submitted to the FMSS HQ P&AM Program Manager for consolidation and upward These reports include:

monetary controls over its personal property. KISAM
AM provides IRS with the official complete record of perpetual inventory accounts for IT and non
IT assets, which meets the control criteria for the IRS general ledger accounts. Accountability in the ﬁscal context includes reporting on the use of funds and recording the events and transac
tions involving an IRS asset. This process provides historical information about the asset’s value throughout its lifecycle.

Note: Territory Disposal Records are maintained for three years and disposition follows the records schedule requirements. Territory acquisition documents are maintained until the asset is excessed/disposed (TD 73-01).
Annual reports must be ﬁled to comply with federal requirements. These include reports to GSA, Treasury, and the FMSS HQ P&AM Program
Reports are compiled by each of the FMSS territories and submitted to the FMSS HQ P&AM Program Manager for consolidation and upward reporting. These reports include:
